sam
2020-06-08T18:03:17.000Z
DIF now allows individual contributors without being members. As Rouven pointed out in an earlier email currently DIF members (Associate members) and individuals who signed the Feedback Agreement can participate in the work carried out by the WG. (please note, Feedback Agreement should be signed by individuals who only represent themselves and they could- and should not represent any of their employers. Preferably only freelancers)  Please send this form to the folks who already meet the individual contributor requirements  and ask them to complete the DocuSign sent after submitting the form.  Additionally, please connect me with the companies who are not individuals and let me share with them the WG charter and pre-explain them the IPR release etc. related to WG contributions so they can sign the release forms as soon as we figured out the legal aspects, as described below.    Related to your ask and the community's signals we started to look into ways to open up certain Working Groups to allow free company contributions as well. It requires additional legal and accounting work therefore it will take another 1-3 weeks until we can announce the changes. The current goal is to open up WGs for contributing companies for free. At least I can promise that we will make sure that even if not all WGs gets open IDWG will have the same participation arrangement as the Secure Data Storage WG.

Number of replies: 0

robert.mitwicki
2021-12-02T13:10:39.000Z
It is never too late :wink: Having all of you here I have interesting topic to address and trying to collect some materials, Security aspect of KERI based identity system. That is in the context of which showed some problems of Lissi - Indy based solution. Long story short they took it down as soon as they got "review" from CCC and showing that actually it was quite easy to break the system (Hijack subdomain - DNS, and do Mitm attack on didcomm)

michal.pietrus
2021-12-07T19:23:21.000Z
I am actually thinking to stop using DID's at all..? The last Mozilla response to DID's was not enthusiastic, especially the last paragraph about blockchains which in the KERI case is not applicable at all. Since `did:keri` will be made in DIF , it's difficult to say about compatibility or interop. Overall should work, but using `did:keri` in the spec (seen some in `ietf-cesr-proof`) may be confusing and leading to mistakes.

griffin.kev

Number of replies: 0

pfeairheller
2022-03-03T14:32:16.000Z
Good Morning Folks- As we move to harden KERIpy for a production implementation of the vLEI ecosystem, we (mostly Sam) analyzed our approach to rotation events for distributed multisig identifiers. In particular, our support for partial rotations (rotating with only a subset of all signers that still satisfies the signature threshold) came under scrutiny. The result was the following issue and subsequent PR addressing the issue. In short, we changed the format for the `n` field and added an `nt` field for all establishment events to support partial rotations. The HackMD referenced in this issue has details of the new events and the issue itself details the logic needed to ensure a secure partial rotation.

Number of replies: 0

pfeairheller
2022-03-03T14:33:20.000Z
The PR is also referenced in the issue if you want to see the implementation in KERIpy along with all the test vectors that broke as a result. :smirk:

Number of replies: 0

ruth
2022-03-08T18:27:54.000Z
<@U024CJMG22J>, here are my next set of questions, prefaced with assumptions: *Assumptions*: 1) Provenant platform will create a hosted cloud wallets in AWS for entity’s 2) Provenant platform will use delegated keys to act on behalf of the holders of the wallets *Questions*: 1) Since private keys need to be stored in an entity’s (hosted) wallet, should the entity’s inception event happen after the wallet is created and run on the server where the wallet is stored? 2) Does the Provenant platform, on behalf of an entity, need to supply the AID to the QVI for it to issue a vLEI to the entity? 3) Who makes the request for a vLEI? 4) When a QVI issues a vLEI to an entity, how does the entity receive the credential offer? 5) GLEIF uses a GLEIF delegated key to issue vLEIs to QVIs, does it also give QVIs a GLEIF delegated key or do QVIs use their own private key to sign credentials they issue? 6) Can a delegated key be created from a delegated key? Who approves the delegated key of a delegated key? 7) Does a request for a delegated key result in a new AID and pair of keys for the delegatee? If yes, does that mean that the delegatee needs a wallet? 8) Please confirm that pre-rotated keys and delegated keys are stored in the holder’s wallet in the secure key storage along with the private key 9) Does an entity with a Validating Agent role need a vLEI? Or does the Validating Agent only vet entities and work with LOUs to issue LEIs?

Number of replies: 0

ruth
2022-03-08T18:29:31.000Z
10) If a wallet is created before an inception event, how is the wallet associated with an entity? Is it by the friendly name of the wallet?

Number of replies: 0

pfeairheller
2022-03-08T20:39:09.000Z
1. Yes, creation of an identifier occurs after the database and keystore is created. From the command line tool, you run `kli init` first and `kli incept` afterwards. 2. There are detailed flows for identity assurance and identifier exchange as part of the vLEI ecosystem. Those need to be followed to ensure secure communication on which the credential issuance is based. 3. There are designated representatives for a Legal Entity who are authorized to request any of the credentials from a QVI 4. There is a credential issuance peer to peer protocol define as a series of `exn` messages. The holder will receive a `exn` message with a `/credential/issue` route. 5. Private keys are never shared with KERI. Each QVI will create an identifier that is delegated from the GLEIF External AID. So the QVI has its own keys for its identifier with is delegated from GLEIF. 6. Yes, a new identifier can specify a key that is also a delegate as its delegator. So it would look like A -> B -> C where A is B's delegator and B is C's delegator. To authorize an establishment event of a delegate, a delegator needs to anchor the establishment event in either an interaction (`ixn`) or a rotation (`rot`) event. So in B's case, she could authorize C's events with an `ixn` event and not require any further action from A. But is B wants to use `rot` events to anchor C's events, those events would have to be verified by A with a corresponding anchor. 7. Yes, a delegate needs its own wallet and holds its own keys. The delegate initiates its own AID, specifying the AID to use as its delegator. 8. All private keys (current and next) are stored in the secure key storage, yes. 9. Validating Agents are part of LEIs and not vLEIs so they won't need vLEI credentials 10. A wallet is merely the database and keystore. An identifier created for that wallet has all its key material stored in the keystore and yes, it is given a user friendly name so human's can remember what it is later.

Number of replies: 0

ruth
2022-03-09T03:19:11.000Z

robert.mitwicki
2022-03-31T09:06:15.000Z
FYI: 
CEN/CLC/JTC19  has approved a  work item aiming to produce a Technical Specification with the following title: "Decentralised Identity Management Model based on Blockchain and other Distributed Ledgers Technologies. –Part 1: Generic Reference Framework".As per document N 103, the scope of the work item is the following: "The proposed standard will specify a reference architecture for decentralised identity management, optionally enabled by distributed ledger technology (DLT) and blockchain systems. The reference architecture aims to natural persons and legal entities and addresses concepts, cross-cutting aspects,   architectural considerations,  and architecture views,  including functional components,  roles, activities, and their relationships with blockchain and DLT.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

pfeairheller

            	
2022-04-11T20:57:48.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I just pushed  to the  repo with all artifacts needed to verify the contained credential.  All files are in a new `interop` directory.  They all have the extension `.json` but most of them contain additional cryptographic material in the form of attachments so they won't validate as JSON files, but will parse in a proper KERI parser.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

ruth

            	
2022-04-20T21:53:29.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Hi Janet, my name is Ruth Choueka, I work with Randy Warshaw. I was wondering if I could possibly ask you questions regarding the wireframes you shared with him? For instance, in the Profile/Contacts/Settings wireframes there are several wireframes for managing aliases. My understanding, from looking at the wireframes, is that an alias can be associated with a default credential, and a profile can have a default alias. Is that right?

What is the purpose of different aliases, does each alias represent a different AID (inception event)?

In the wireframes shown, the *default alias* value is the same as the *name* value, is that always the case?

Regarding the witness URLs, the user has to enter them, he does not have the option of choosing them from a drop down list of possible witnesses?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 4

				
						

							

								
								
janet

								
2022-04-20T21:53:29.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Hi Ruth,

We're actually working on revising those, so these are great questions! :relaxed:. We're likely going to go with last used over setting a default AID. Each one does represent a different AID. You can name it whatever you want, the name just seems like the more likely option. 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
janet

								
2022-04-20T21:53:29.000Z

2022-05-31T15:10:30.000Z

<@U03EUG009MY> there's also CESR spec worth reading as it is the underlying protocol to stream the data across network participants. As opposed to OOBI's spec, this is a bit lower level, but might be worth to take a look of how it works.

pfeairheller

            	
2022-06-30T17:14:47.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Now that the `keripy` development team has finished the big push to complete the vLEI XBRL Annual Report Signing Pilot (see press release here:  ) we are updating the branches and development process to live up to our commitment to have a more stable `main` branch in our repository.

We just renamed our primary branch from `master` to `main` and then created the `development` branch which will be used for all active development moving forward.  Any PRs should be submitted against `development` and we, as a community will agree when it is time to cut a next release from `development` and merge all outstanding changes into `main`.  We will commit to ensuring that all unit tests, demo scripts, command line commands and REST APIs will work as advertised at all times on the `main` branch moving forward.  (There will be a series of PRs over the next week or so to get us there).

If you have already cloned or forked the `keripy` repo, you can run the following commands to update your local copy of the primary branch from `master` to `main`.


git branch -m master main
git fetch origin
git branch -u origin/main main
git remote set-head origin -a
Of course changing `origin` to whatever your remote is named for the `WebOfTrust/keripy` remote repository.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

I already had cloned the keripy repo. So I used github today to sync  WebOfTrust/keripy to my  remote repo.

git fetch origin
But the third:
hvc@Henks-Mbp20 keripy-1 % git branch -u origin/main main
error: the requested upstream branch ‘origin/main’ does not exist

Any idea what I do wrong?

if you want to align with keripy from weboftrust:
```cd keripy/
$ git remote add wot git@github.com:WebOfTrust/keripy
$ git fetch wot 
$ git checkout -b main
$ git reset --hard wot/main```

2byrds

            	
2022-07-13T13:36:16.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I’m trying to mentally solidify how the backer connection/configuration information along with the backer id list is updated/evolves in KERI.  I read through the white paper regarding inception/rotation events and the configuration of witness list/threshold.  but i’m still not convinced I can describe a controller porting their ledger backed KERL from one ledger to another (similar to pruning and adding new witnesses… but  i think there is some nuanced differences).  I am talking to <@U024CJMG22J> on Thursday, so if that is a better venue to discuss, i can be patient :)

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

            	
2022-07-13T14:42:41.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	

Hi Lance, for what I’ve understood is that Ledger-registered backers are a secondary root-of-trust at best. It’s an extra guarantee. The primary root of trust is the KEL, which is cryptographically verifiable to this primary root-of-trust (PKI). Afaik KERI doesn’t organize portability between two ledger-registered backers (from one ledger to another), However, KERI is a portable autonomic identifier system in itself by design, and you’re free to use as many blockchains as you like to create secondary roots of trusts. But how efficient or useful that’ll be….
Phil definitely has a better thorough understanding of KERI and all of its technicalities. But this is my take on it, feel free to correct me if I am wrong (because I might well be :slightly_smiling_face: )

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
2byrds

            	
2022-07-13T15:46:25.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
thank you <@U02PA6UQ6BV>. the glossary is really helpful for reconnecting to these terms, as I get to know them.  we love the root-of-trust model of KERI to enable portable AIDs, for sure! I’m currently thinking through the  ledger as a replacement for the witness network.  if we do that (not just discovery nor hybrid model, like we discussed yesterday), then there will be configuration in the Inception Event of the AID that includes configuration for the ledger backer oracle connection information?  If so, then on rotation i should be able to update my oracle list (similar to updating witnesses, and witness thresholds,etc).  but i’m not certain if the backer configuration is separate from the backer ids and then how the mechanics of changing that during rotation might work.  Hopefully I can address some of my misunderstandings when I talk to Phil about the GLEIF witness network.  looking forward to it!

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

            	
2022-07-13T16:13:09.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Interesting, Lance, I’ll follow your efforts. Here again my two cents:
The problem with a ledger being the single root-of-trust for a witness (if I understand your idea correctly) is that its key are not rotatable. You’d need a transaction on the ledger to rotate the controlling key of the witness, which leaves you locked in: not portable anymore (locked to the silo / blockchain of this specific ledger), it’s become algoritmic identifier not an autonomic one. I believe KERI needs AID based witnesses to be able to offer KERI’s
• security model: duplicity detection and reconciliation
• features: portable identifiers, secure attribution over the web

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
2byrds

            	
2022-07-13T16:28:50.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Good points!  I hadn’t spent much time unwinding the witness/backer AID and how that interplays with the user KEL Inception/Rotation Event configuration.  Great concepts to consider and unwind.  Looking forward to discussing more as I learn

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-07-14T03:54:13.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
> The problem with a ledger being the single root-of-trust for a witness (if I understand your idea correctly) is that its key are not rotatable.
Thanks for drawing attention to this Henk. That makes sense.

hvancann

            	
2022-07-26T15:41:02.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I’ll create an info page in the main Terms & Edu repo:  with the usual links to Zoom, agenda, etc.
I suggest to start NEXT Thursday 28 7am PT  (4PM CEST) with this agenda:
1. Why are we doing the Terms & Edu call?
2. What are the main sources of info / concepts / terms currently for KERI/ACDC
3. How to sync glossaries with the outside world, a proposal
4. Ho to set up KERI/ACDC education at various levels of understanding.
5. <any other pressing questions / issues / suggestions ?>


            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

Number of replies: 3

				
						

							

								
								
michal.pietrus

								
2022-07-27T12:31:07.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U035R1TFEET>, i am not sure there are any recordings, but we currently target:
• society (ie. birth attestation)
• pharma (clinical trails) 
• a use case for supply chain
KERI is universal. Any kind of use case with multiple governed parties involved and where authentic data comes into play is applicable.

2022-07-27T12:31:07.000Z

daniel.hardman

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
daniel.hardman

            	
2022-08-05T12:08:44.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U02PA6UQ6BV>: I had a look at your terms wiki. Very impressive work, and I think this will be immensely valuable to the entire community.

I turned on automatic glossary generation for the wiki, and configured it slightly. Here is the URL for the glossary that goes with your terms wiki: 

Notice that when you hover over a term, there's an icon at the left that allows you to link to a specific term. When you click the icon, it copies onto your clipboard a link to that term. For example, here's the term "digital signature": 

I noticed a few things about the data on the wiki pages that was making the glossary sub-optimal, so I fixed things here and there. Some things you might check if something doesn't render the way you want:

1. Images as displayed in raw wiki markdown have a different canvas size than images in the glossary. For this reason, it is often best to force images to be a specific size that will be good for the glossary. You can see how I've done this in the wiki page for authentic chained data container, for example: 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
daniel.hardman

            	
2022-08-05T12:10:01.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
2. The headers for additional sections of your wiki page should not be more indented than the header for Definition. If Definition begins with two hashes: `## Definition`, then subsequent sections should also begin with 2. If they don't, then the glossary generation may only display the more indented content.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

            	
2022-08-05T12:15:53.000Z

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-08-10T19:28:09.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U03RTP08W3B> ACDC has been implemented inside of `keripy`.  We have full credential issuance, revocation and streaming support in both the REST API as well as the command line.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-08-10T19:29:43.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
If you look at the script `scripts/demo/vLEI/issue-xbrl-attestation.sh` it show cases creating a chain of ACDC credentials culminating in a data attestation (non-issuee credential) using the command line.  It is a great place to start understanding the ACDC implementation inside `keripy`

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

daniel.hardman

            	
2022-08-26T13:22:59.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Yes, I am aware of the SAID spec. It was just the AID that felt under-specified to me. Perhaps it doesn't really merit a spec. I see that Henk's definition references some verbiage about it being a CESR-encoded "qualified cryptographic primitive". Given that "CESR-encoded" conveys a wealth of requirements about structure, only the "qualified cryptographic primitive" phrase seems ambiguous.

pfeairheller

            	
2022-08-26T16:30:12.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U03RLLP2CR5> I do believe that AID repo was a placeholder that we probably don't need any longer.  And yes, the structure of an AID is documented in CESR, but I think someone would be hard pressed to understand that on the surface.  Since CESR is an encoding format that is not specific to KERI, or identity for that matter, a real definition probably doesn't belong there.

Perhaps as <@U024KC347B4> suggested we should add something to the SAID spec that specifically defines an AID.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

hvancann

            	
2022-08-26T21:35:45.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Whatever definition we choose to prevail, we might need to diversify our glossary terminology, level* : autonomic identifier (AID) -> Phil Windley’s def, level*** is our internal exact definition that even the average SSI expert might have a hard time to get his/her head around.
An  autonomic identifier*** is an elaboration of autonomic identifier*? Put differently: A KERI AID is in the Phil Windley set?

kent

								
2022-09-21T21:35:22.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Hahaha! Fact check with DIDs and VCs. Precisely what we knew would happen.

It’s time we also kept a record of who claims what is misinformation so we can interrogate the claimants as well as the claims.

Reputation systems to the rescue.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2022-09-21T21:35:22.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think it’s KERI & ACDC related. KERI for secure attribution over the web and ACDC for veracity (based on VCs).
It’d be interesting to see if specific ACDC stuff like correlation prevention and step by step disclosure could be a killer feature for the CAI members.
But indeed Kent brings up another interesting aspect: what is misinformation? Everybody needs to commit themselves to signing off content and schemas, also the CAI members themselves. We’ll see who’s the most obvious spreader of fake news, maybe the ones that shout the loudest for CAI :joy:

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2022-09-21T21:35:22.000Z

griffin.kev

            	
2022-09-28T20:01:38.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
It is worth noting that while the ACDC core community, for the most part, is tightly coupled with KERI right now that the "official" home of ACDC is within ToIP and the "Technology Stack Working Group Authentic Chained Data Containers Task Force" (#tswg-acdc-tf).

There is a toip slack for acdc and not all people who are in the official one are here - so conversations pertinent to ACDC should occur in toip slack.

pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T21:46:34.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Hey Folks, sorry about the delayed responses, Sam is on vacation, I am dealing with family issues and Kevin is taking up all the slack with GLEIF and our go live date of November 1st.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T21:47:46.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I'll give an over all witness description here and then try to answer specific questions where they were asked.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T21:56:44.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Each witness is independent and keeps local copies of all KELs that they know about.  We have not implement gossip protocols yet so as an alternative we have implemented the policy that all controllers are responsible for propagating their key events to all their witnesses and then pass out all receipts from each witness to the other witnesses.   In addition, the controller is also responsible for introducing witnesses to each other when a controller uses them together.  This eliminates the need to bootstrap any kind of witness introduction while we don't have gossip implemented.

Gossip is dependent on UDP protocol support which is dependent on CESR streaming of events themselves which Sam has started but not finished because revised rotation rules has taken precedence.   Once we pop that stack and have gossip working, witness (and watcher) communication will be simplified.  But for now, keripy controllers make sure to introduce all witnesses to each other (admittedly a little chatty), sends events to each witness, collect all receipts from each witness and then send them back out to the other witnesses.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T22:10:30.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
As for HTTP vs TCP.  Witnesses do expose a TCP port which will work fine for direct streaming of KERI events.  However, the keripy agent and command line exclusively use CESR streaming over HTTP.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T22:11:27.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
The reason is that we had to focus on HTTP in order to support mailboxes for controllers that do not have persistent Internet connection and that was built using HTTP.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-11T22:16:57.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
So all the configuration we use currently favors HTTP for all communication

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-10-11T23:55:24.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Thanks a lot <@U024CJMG22J> . I have no rush on any answer. I just throw here so other can catch up as well.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-10-11T23:57:08.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
One more conceptual question regarding witnesses based on what you said: can a witness  witness more than one agent at the same time?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-12T00:00:29.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Yes, the current witness implementation in keripy is promiscuous.  As long as a controller commits to a witness in its KEL, the witness will provide a signed receipt.  It is assumed that any deployment of witnesses will provide authentication over their witnesses to prevent them from witnessing for any AID.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-10-12T00:04:42.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Fair. At least for an implementation point of view I like the idea of having a witness validating multiple KELs.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-12T00:07:37.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Non-transferable identifiers and receipting key events are both so cheap, witness infrastructure can be deployed to support any configuration you need.  Whether that is multiple AIDs using the same witness AID or one for one AID to witness AID, the protocol should scale to any level.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-12T00:08:30.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I imagine SAS witness services will discover multiple scaling models.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-10-12T00:37:28.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
witness/watcher as a service is floating  in my mind

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-10-17T00:34:01.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
How is `kli` installed?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-10-17T00:45:43.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
when you install requirements with `pip install -r requirements.txt`, it actually works with setuptools packaging, and an entry_point is created for `kli` . At the end it's a python call to `keri.app.cli.kli:main`

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 2

				
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-10-17T00:45:43.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I was looking for the following:
```### Local installation
Once all dependencies are installed and working then run:

`$ python3 -m pip install -e ./`

Then you can run 

`$ kli version` 

to get a version string similar to the following: 

`0.6.7````

kent

            	
2022-10-17T01:42:01.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I was looking for the following:

### Local installation
Once all dependencies are installed and working then run:

`$ python3 -m pip install -e ./`

Then you can run 

`$ kli version` 

to get a version string similar to the following: 

`0.6.7
`

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-18T17:17:49.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I meant to bring this up on today's call but did not get a chance.

Does anyone know anything about, or have any experience with the following public key algorithm:



GLEIF is being asked about supporting it in the vLEI ecosystem and my first reaction is, "that's a bad idea" but really don't know much about it.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 2

				
						

							

								
								
michal.pietrus

								
2022-10-18T17:17:49.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Found a paper  discussing this algorithm. There:
```At present,
SM2 is also used in blind signatures, proxy
signatures, threshold cryptosystems and secure
cooperation between two parties. However, no one
has conducted research on SM2's batch verification
algorithm. This article proposes SM2 digital
signatures A batch verification algorithm for the
same signer and different signers.```
Seems someone found it useful. However, due to the language barrier you might have difficulties to find anything about SM2. The published  on IETF is indeed in English, but would definitely require formal audit.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2022-10-18T17:17:49.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Than ks <@U02N7K951DW>

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
michal.pietrus

            	
2022-10-19T10:51:44.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Found a paper  discussing this algorithm. There:

At present,
SM2 is also used in blind signatures, proxy
signatures, threshold cryptosystems and secure
cooperation between two parties. However, no one
has conducted research on SM2's batch verification
algorithm. This article proposes SM2 digital
signatures A batch verification algorithm for the
same signer and different signers.
Seems someone found it useful. However, due to the language barrier you might have difficulties to find anything about SM2. The published  on IETF is indeed in English, but would definitely require formal audit.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-10-19T20:13:44.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Than ks <@U02N7K951DW>

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
petteri.stenius

            	
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Hi all,

I have a couple of questions about credentials

1. Are there plans for supporting querying credentials by attribute value or metadata parameters? For example letting a credential issuer query issued credentials by LEI code or by date of issuance?
2. Semantics of OOR and ECR authorization credentials. Who issues OOR and ECR authorization credentials and who is the recipient? What values will be set in personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole attributes of the authorization credential?


3. Extending credential schema. For example how can I extend ECR credential schema with an email attribute?
4. Credential expiration. The roles that OOR and ECR credentials represent often have a known end date based on some business contract for example. Is there a way to set expiration date on these credentials?

Thanks!

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 5

				
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I want to know these answers as well. Good questions. Here’s my understanding from what the KERI whitepaper and IETF specs say:

1) querying credentials by metadata is supported and querying by value is part of the graduated disclosure mechanism so yes, support exists or is planned for both.

2)looks like VLEI specific credential types. Only a vLEI expert can answer completely. I suspect either a QVI or a company itself issues both of those types. Don’t take my word for it. I imagine the values are context specific. If you are looking for a type system to select from a distinct set of values there may be a specification somewhere that constrains those values. Otherwise the values are up to the issuer.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
3) extending the credential schema should be doable by adding another ACDC linked to the original as ACDCs are an extensible graph structure.

4) there’s a way to set the expiration date on any credential since an expiration date is a regular property of a credential. Regardless of an expiration date you will want to verify control authority for a credential by verifying KELs.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
ruth

								
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
My understanding is that only a QVI can issue an OOR, but it requires an AUTH credential () from the Legal Entity to the QVI; the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
ruth

								
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I believe the ECR can be issued by either the Legal Entity or by a QVI if the Legal Entity issues an AUTH credential () to the QVI.  In either case the Legal Entity must hold a valid Legal Entity vLEI credential.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
petteri.stenius

								
2022-10-24T09:00:38.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Yes, the QVI is the only who can issue OOR credentials and the QVI can also issue ECR credentials.
The QVI issued OOR/ECR credentials require OOR/ECR authorization credentials.
I would like to understand the authorization use case.
The OOR/ECR authorization credentials have basically the same attributes as the actual OOR/ECR credentials (personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole).
Is the LE authorizing the QVI to issue OOR/ECR credentials one at a time, where every QVI issued credential requires a separate authorization from the LE?
I would have expected authorization contract to be on more generic level where the LE authorizes a QVI to issue any OOR/ECR credentials.

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-10-24T13:07:07.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I want to know these answers as well. Good questions. Here’s my understanding from what the KERI whitepaper and IETF specs say:

1) querying credentials by metadata is supported and querying by value is part of the graduated disclosure mechanism so yes, support exists or is planned for both.

2)looks like VLEI specific credential types. Only a vLEI expert can answer completely. I suspect either a QVI or a company itself issues both of those types. Don’t take my word for it. I imagine the values are context specific. If you are looking for a type system to select from a distinct set of values there may be a specification somewhere that constrains those values. Otherwise the values are up to the issuer.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-10-24T13:09:14.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
3) extending the credential schema should be doable by adding another ACDC linked to the original as ACDCs are an extensible graph structure.

4) there’s a way to set the expiration date on any credential since an expiration date is a regular property of a credential. Regardless of an expiration date you will want to verify control authority for a credential by verifying KELs.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

Yes, the QVI is the only who can issue OOR credentials and the QVI can also issue ECR credentials.
The QVI issued OOR/ECR credentials require OOR/ECR authorization credentials.
I would like to understand the authorization use case.
The OOR/ECR authorization credentials have basically the same attributes as the actual OOR/ECR credentials (personLegalName, officialRole and engagementContextRole).
Is the LE authorizing the QVI to issue OOR/ECR credentials one at a time, where every QVI issued credential requires a separate authorization from the LE?
I would have expected authorization contract to be on more generic level where the LE authorizes a QVI to issue any OOR/ECR credentials.

In this morning’s call about making JSON-LD `@context` optional, I thought I heard Sam say that the DID answer was to make it required and that this was a mistake. However, in the VC issue 947 I see comments like  that indicate that the resolution was to NOT make it required. Am I misunderstanding?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 6

				
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2022-10-25T15:12:37.000Z

kent

								
2022-10-25T15:12:37.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Yes Trent, I just got to that part of the thread and as Rodolfo said `@context` is not required for plain JSON yet it is required for JSON-LD.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
daniel.hardman

								
2022-10-25T15:12:37.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think we tried to summarize too soon.

Right now, `@context` is required in all cases. Issue 947 is a request to make it not required for plain JSON. However, it looks like this issue is going to be closed by denying the request. That would mean it is always required. :disappointed:

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-10-25T15:12:37.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
How disappointing. It was an illuminating thread even if only to be close how committed the W3C is to RDF. It would be great if the spec was relabeled to JSON-LD Credentials.

I have some catching up to do. I got to your comment last Tuesday, Daniel, and didn’t get much further. It was a long read to get to that point since I had to go read up on a few things to give me context, no pun intended.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
daniel.hardman

kent

            	
2022-10-25T17:30:06.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I pulled the KERI EXN message from `keripy/ref/Peer2PeerCredentials.md` and it didn’t have an `s` field so I added one. I know that might not be right, I’m just trying to illustrate what I understand of the ACDC spec. I copied the `$id` field from the schema in the `JSON Schema for VC Template` section in the same *.md* file.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-10-25T17:31:31.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
The ACDC spec in section 3.2 says
> Correspondingly, the value of the top-level schema, `s`, field MUST be the SAID included in the schema’s top-level `$id` field.
Which is why I thought the `s` field could be added to the `exn` message’s `vc` section to illustrate where the value of the `$id` field would go. I’m sure I got something wrong, though is this headed in the right direction?

pfeairheller

            	
2022-11-02T20:51:53.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
For those tracking the `main` branch of keripy, we just pushed all the changes from the latest development branch into main.

The major change for this upgrade was the Neo changes that create stable transformations on CESR.  Also included is work in the Hab and Matter classes towards support for the new revised rotation rules to more fully support custodial key management.  Finally, a bunch of upgrades to the `kli` commands are included.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

hvancann

								
2022-11-18T14:11:49.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Another silo ID system, tied the ETH blockchain. “Privacy first”, yes, and security last?
I am not impressed by this marketing writeup and share the concerns of the critics.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2022-11-18T14:11:49.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
‘
“While (Polygon ID) uses biometric information for verification purposes, that data isn’t provided to anyone unless the user gives explicit permission,” he said
’
There we go. Biometric data should be encrypted by priv keys the subject controls. Any other mechanism is subject to fraud and deceit.

‘
“While (Polygon ID) uses biometric information for verification purposes, that data isn’t provided to anyone unless the user gives explicit permission,” he said
’
There we go. Biometric data should be encrypted by priv keys the subject controls. Any other mechanism is subject to fraud and deceit.

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
robert.mitwicki

            	
2022-11-18T15:23:52.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
 Due to recent activities in keri community and some uncertainties have arisen in regards of the license of Human Colossus Foundation implementation would like to provide you some insights. As you all know HCF have very specific strategy regarding protecting the community and the implementation which we are working  on. We invested already quite some resources and money into what we have build. Our vision could be described as: building with community for the community. Based on that we did quite in deep evaluation of different licensing options and we ended up (in our opinion) with one of the best option which is EUPL1.2. I know that a lot of people do not have a good understanding of that part and sometimes misinterpret the consequences of the license. This is why we prepared short summary of our reasoning and argumentation why we pick EUPL and why it matters for us.
Here you can find it: 

I would love to here everyone take on that and prepare questions if you have any.

As you know as HCF we are working on many components of KERI ecosystem and we are pretty advance in it, including keriox, cesrox and said all that is already separated, and is used in multiple projects. Obviously we don't mind if that work would be duplicated because you would find a good reason to not go with EUPL license. But as far as I know there is no reason to do so. And if someone would be able to prove benefits of other license for those components which fulfills our demands we are willing to change that license for benefits of community. Until that would happen, we would protect our community investment in a way as described above.

I already requested to have a slot on the KERI call to provide some more insights and hear everyone opinion in that regards and eventually address some of those questions. If everything goes right we would have a chance to speak on next KERI Call but before hand feel free to provide your feedback and post questions in this thread.

Best regards
Head of Technology Council at Human Colossus Foundation

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
harold_carr

            	
2022-11-18T19:11:36.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
CESR for 1st year wizard (notes from IIW presentation): 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-11-18T22:02:54.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Is  the best start for building an authentication system and authorization system using KERI?

I am mapping the KERI protocol onto a traditional sign-in and authorization model.
It seems that the sign-in would be replaced with a profile acknowledgment based on a stored credential in some local browser storage that then personalized a user’s experience.

This requires a web wallet or web data satchel (help me name this). Do we have any examples of storing credentials or keypairs in indexeddb? I know it’s not the best solution though I’m just doing a POC prototype.

If there are no examples then it seems all I need to do for a web is the following:
1. The ability to create, store, and recover a keypair, inception and rotation,
2. The ability to send messages to witnesses and store receipts
3. The ability to view stored credentials and 
4. to send existing credentials (graduated disclosure)
5. The ability to issue new credentials
6. The ability to sign events, or respond to signing challenges.
I’m still reading through the SKWA document so maybe it covers many of these points.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-11-18T22:05:37.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
The vision for SKWA is much lighter on the client side than you have expressed.  The idea is to only provide key generation and event signing in the client.  _Everything_ else stays in the agent.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 8

				
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-11-18T22:05:37.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Got it, thank you. Once I finish SKWA I’ll think about this all and circle back.

Perhaps a conversation about how we envisioned it might work could provide some insight before you finished it.

griffin.kev

            	
2022-11-18T22:06:03.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U013F46SDRR> Thanks the write up and clarifications. I am not sure what ‘activities and uncertainties’ you are referring to, but, I certainly have made numerous references to the license change as a reason keriox ‘exists’ under web of trust, but have always qualified it with “the HCF guys are so awesome, they donated a version before the license change”. purely for clarification of why that repository exists at all.

I’m not sure of other peoples intentions for keriox, but the notion of cesrox came about after the last IIW where CESR was identified as a source of "this is hard to adopt" - so we used the keriox you contributed under the apache2 license to start cesrox (this IIW) we're currently in the process of completing changes for the "neo" changes and subsequently the indexer changes in keripy, I'll push Phil and I's branch - which while incomplete shows progress to being parallel with keripy in terms of cesr.

Something that the upstream keriox impls would want to do as well.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 1

				
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2022-11-18T22:06:03.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
By ‘activities and uncertainties’ I mean that people are not sure how the know-how brought by HCF can be reused and how we can collaborate since we under another license. A lot of people treat EUPL as GPL which leads to wrong assumption.

Yes we (and Jolocom) contributed keriox to weboftrust as the work started on Apache 2 and we didn't wanted just simply pull that from DIF. We decided to switch to EUPL for better protection of the community behind it. What was already done stays under that license we cannot withdraw it or at least won't be nice to try to hid it anyway.

I am fine with two project under different license. We have strong arguments why we chose the EUPL - mainly to protect the community and avoid situation that private company would pick it and extend it without sharing back, causing forks and split of the community or even the protocols. It is beneficial for whole community if we would continue use EUPL. But as I said it is our world view and complete understand if other would take thoughtful decision based on facts and not just false assumption.

We are investing quite a lot into the development of those components and I bet that other community members would like to do that as well. Doing it twice it is just a bit of wast resources especially if there would not be any good argument for that.

Especially that we are almost done with cesrox as a separate package.

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-11-18T22:06:34.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Got it, thank you. Once I finish SKWA I’ll think about this all and circle back.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2022-11-18T22:09:00.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
We've put a lot of thought into SKWA and written some things down that we haven't had a chance to review thoroughly at the dev meetings.  Perhaps a conversation about how we envisioned it might work could provide some insight before you finished it.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2022-11-18T22:09:49.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
(neo is changes to the way we do padding and will be evident in the PR to cesrox)

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
robert.mitwicki

            	
2022-11-19T07:51:21.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
By ‘activities and uncertainties’ I mean that people are not sure how the know-how brought by HCF can be reused and how we can collaborate since we under another license. A lot of people treat EUPL as GPL which leads to wrong assumption.

Yes we (and Jolocom) contributed keriox to weboftrust as the work started on Apache 2 and we didn't wanted just simply pull that from DIF. We decided to switch to EUPL for better protection of the community behind it. What was already done stays under that license we cannot withdraw it or at least won't be nice to try to hid it anyway.

I am fine with two project under different license. We have strong arguments why we chose the EUPL - mainly to protect the community and avoid situation that private company would pick it and extend it without sharing back, causing forks and split of the community or even the protocols. It is beneficial for whole community if we would continue use EUPL. But as I said it is our world view and complete understand if other would take thoughtful decision based on facts and not just false assumption.

We are investing quite a lot into the development of those components and I bet that other community members would like to do that as well. Doing it twice it is just a bit of wast resources especially if there would not be any good argument for that.

Especially that we are almost done with cesrox as a separate package.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
trent

            	
2022-11-19T20:54:21.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U013F46SDRR> Thank you for the explanation of EUPL, and especially the link to the full strategy write-up at the Foundation. This helps me with some of my previous reservations, and I see EUPL as a valid approach. I might be willing to support the development under that license.

— though I personally prefer the most-permissive and least-wordy licence. There is space for more permissive licensing. We’ve learned from GPL & LGPL that people will shy away from viral & restrictive licenses which hurts adoption; that doc makes the point that even Google has mistakenly marked this license as unusable … and although it’s a mistake, it is a barrier. Honestly, I think SQLite has done the right thing with ; sure, it may not force the community to contribute back, but it’s clear… and I see the threat to adoption & collaboration (whether by mistake or by malice) as the bigger threat, higher than the threat of someone failing to give back.

But I’m now more willing to follow the group if they want to build on THC code.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 1

				
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2022-11-19T20:54:21.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Completely agree that lengthy and complicated licenses does not help regular users to jump on board. But keep in mind that in many cases licenses like that does not have any grounding in the real law. For individual person maybe that is not very important but when you deal with businesses or governmental services you can't simply skip that bit.
Or define "do good not evil" - good for whom, what means good?. If you face serious business and face their legal department you would bounce of it relatively quickly.
Community needs support to navigate through this space anyway. This is why we team up with lawyers to make sure that we get it right and we are able to protect our community in the right way.  Through our experience we went through many open source communities and initiatives and personal must say that I am feed up with the direction which this takes. "Open Source" become marketing tool, nobody think about collaboration and community, Big tech companies used that to warm up their image. It  lead to a trap called "platforms" and providing free development force for those who actually can monetize specific technology. You use open source and think that your are independent because you have control over code but you are under control of corporate machine. One of many  examples is android as OS which is great open source OS but actually without using google services this operating system is useless and not user friendly, You can NOT have simple push notification in your own "open source" app running on open source service, using open source backend without google having stake in that.

Decentralization is not only about technology it is as well about governance and distribution of power. Letting everyone do what ever they want (more permissive licensing) is not always good for what we do.

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-11-19T21:58:58.000Z

rodolfo.miranda

            	
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Is there a specific message for a witness to tell the agent that its ley events won’t be witnessed?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 6

				
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I haven’t heard of this though I’m looking it up. Will you ask this on Stackoverflow? The KERI tag has no questions:

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Let’s get that tag started! I’ll post my answer here and there.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
A  message is the closest kind of event I could find that might serve this purpose. Nothing else jumps out at me yet. It would seem odd that a witness would refuse to witness a controller’s key events given that the controller can select its own witnesses. The following quote from section 10.2 *Indirect Replay Mode* of the white paper illustrates this fact:
> _The reliance on a designated set of witnesses provides several advantages. The first is that the_
> _identifier’s trust basis is not locked to any given witness or set of witnesses but may be transferred_
> _at the controller’s choosing._

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
So, given that a controller selects its own witnesses it is the responsibility of the controller to validate the suitability of each witness prior to including that witness in an inception or rotation event as a declared witness.

As a part of the witness evaluation process I could see value in adding a protocol-level event for a given KERI agent (witness, watcher, juror, judge) to indicate it is not able to or will refuse to be a witness for a given controller, though this delves into business-process specific decisions that are likely bespoke to a given implementation and thus don’t yet make sense to add to KERI itself.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I asked because a witness may stop responding  and will be up to the controlled to check why. However the witness may have valid reasons that can be communicated directly (lack of resources, unpaid service, etc)

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2022-11-23T22:47:40.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
for example, are the GLEIF production witnesses  willing to accept KEL from any agent? what about a spasm?

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2022-11-29T16:23:57.000Z

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

A  message is the closest kind of event I could find that might serve this purpose. Nothing else jumps out at me yet. It would seem odd that a witness would refuse to witness a controller’s key events given that the controller can select its own witnesses. The following quote from section 10.2 *Indirect Replay Mode* of the white paper illustrates this fact:
> _The reliance on a designated set of witnesses provides several advantages. The first is that the_
> _identifier’s trust basis is not locked to any given witness or set of witnesses but may be transferred_
> _at the controller’s choosing._

kent

            	
2022-11-29T16:35:32.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
So, given that a controller selects its own witnesses it is the responsibility of the controller to validate the suitability of each witness prior to including that witness in an inception or rotation event as a declared witness.

As a part of the witness evaluation process I could see value in adding a protocol-level event for a given KERI agent (witness, watcher, juror, judge) to indicate it is not able to or will refuse to be a witness for a given controller, though this delves into business-process specific decisions that are likely bespoke to a given implementation and thus don’t yet make sense to add to KERI itself.

kent

            	
2022-12-06T22:30:18.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
For the purposes of SKWA what is the definition of control? Is it having physical possession of and root access to a device?
Here’s the statement for reference:
> The server may be deemed somewhat secure if it was in the client’s control at boot-up but may notbe continuously in the client’s control through out its run time.
I’m trying to understand whether I introduce unacceptable security problems by having a SKWA client be on a mobile device and a SKWA-compatible KERI full node in a cloud server I don’t physically control.

daniel.hardman

            	
2023-01-04T15:52:02.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
: I would like to invite members of the KERI community to a special presentation/proposal about how to bring several different community efforts together -- folks working on DIDComm, as well as Hyperledger Aries, Trust over IP, Decentralized Web Nodes, KERI. The meeting will be this coming Monday, Jan 9 at 9 pm Central Europe, 3 pm Eastern, 1 pm Mountain, noon Pacific. It is on a Zoom bridge owned by DIF, but it is allocated to the DIDComm User Group rather than the DIDComm Working Group. This means the call is open to everyone, not just DIF members. Please come, and please spread the word. The Zoom link for this meeting is: .

neil.thomson

            	
2023-01-11T03:42:30.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 1

				
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2023-01-11T03:42:30.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
thanks <@U03R27M4FM3> I missed the call but watched the recording and I am missing some argumentation on the main point which I believe triggered the idea for GUT, if I may ask  <@U03RLLP2CR5> why you think that there is no proper mindset in place in those communities to be collaborative? Do you have specific examples?

From perspective of HCF (and HCF is part of few of those communities DIF, KERI, ToIP, Aries) we found it very collaborative, and lack of adoption of those specific technologies is more a problem of specific use cases or lack of time to contribute (at least in our view). Not sure how the additional umbrella can help here, wouldn't that be additional overhead?  Happy to learn about what obstacles you encounter to achieve what you presented about GUT.

It reminds me a bit the situation from roughly 3 years ago where we ended up in similar position and we tried to tied governance, identity and data space, to have holistic framework for digital economy and we tried with Aries, DIF and later at ToIP but at the end we found that  each of the community is lead by different needs and was hard to enforce holistic view. This is how HCF was created. So far we where able to unify all above into one stack and linking all technologies created in different place (contributing in those places in the same time) into what you would call GUT. If you didn't I recommend to read introduction to DDE Stack: 

We continue sharing and promoting our achievements in all mentioned communities but we know how hard is to break the ice in a way to think about certain things and hard to enforce it. Based on our experience just following Unix philosophy is more then enough and helps with adoption. This is how we were able to introduce OCA into Aries ecosystem and same way we are building keri components (cesr, sai, tel and more). Happy to hear your experience and understand the reasoning.

From perspective of HCF (and HCF is part of few of those communities DIF, KERI, ToIP, Aries) we found it very collaborative, and lack of adoption of those specific technologies is more a problem of specific use cases or lack of time to contribute (at least in our view). Not sure how the additional umbrella can help here, wouldn't that be additional overhead?  Happy to learn about what obstacles you encounter to achieve what you presented about GUT.

It reminds me a bit the situation from roughly 3 years ago where we ended up in similar position and we tried to tied governance, identity and data space, to have holistic framework for digital economy and we tried with Aries, DIF and later at ToIP but at the end we found that  each of the community is lead by different needs and was hard to enforce holistic view. This is how HCF was created. So far we where able to unify all above into one stack and linking all technologies created in different place (contributing in those places in the same time) into what you would call GUT. If you didn't I recommend to read introduction to DDE Stack: 

We continue sharing and promoting our achievements in all mentioned communities but we know how hard is to break the ice in a way to think about certain things and hard to enforce it. Based on our experience just following Unix philosophy is more then enough and helps with adoption. This is how we were able to introduce OCA into Aries ecosystem and same way we are building keri components (cesr, sai, tel and more). Happy to hear your experience and understand the reasoning.

rodolfo.miranda

            	
2023-01-19T21:49:17.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
The Registrar backer stores the witnesses KEL in a Registry that by itself provides a secondary root of trust. Ledgers are a well know fit because they provide some guarantees on the ordering of the events, timestamp, etc. Of course, that trust came from the trustfulness of the ledger, how secure and how descentralizad it is for example. Can WDN be considered as a secondary root of trust? who controls them?

hvancann

								
2023-01-19T21:49:17.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U03P53FCYB1> writes: ‘Ledgers are a well know fit because they provide some guarantees on the ordering of the events, timestamp, etc.’ -> My take would be that the witness KELs themselves have the ordering in control by the sequence numbers of the individual events and the ‘first seen, can’t unsee’ principle?
I might be missing something. Please let me know.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-01-19T21:49:17.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Yes, the "first seen" principle is key in backers. They write to a ledger that can not be altered (supposedly), so the duplicity problem by forking the KEL is hard to achieve. They may also provide a discovery mechanism to resolve AIDs in a given ecosystem.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-01-19T21:49:17.000Z

kent

            	
2023-01-26T22:04:26.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
What does challenge and response provide?
I’m looking specifically at the `challenge.sh` script. I see OOBI generation and resolution and then challenging. I understand why OOBIs are needed for discovery purposes.
What purpose does challenge and response serve?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 3

				
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-01-26T22:04:26.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Multifactor Auth

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2023-01-26T22:04:26.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
thanks

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-01-26T22:04:26.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
you provide an OOBI and through OOBI resolution you get end-verifiable proof of current key state.  Then in a live session you challenge the controller who signs the challenge phrase proving control of the private keys.

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-01-26T22:05:06.000Z

pfeairheller

            	
2023-01-26T22:06:10.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
you provide an OOBI and through OOBI resolution you get end-verifiable proof of current key state.  Then in a live session you challenge the controller who signs the challenge phrase proving control of the private keys.

pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-03T04:11:52.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I have been tasked with doing presentations to a US government agency (that will remain unnamed) for the purpose of teaching them about the vLEi ecosystem (KERI, CESR, ACDC, etc).  I was given a list of questions to answer, many of which started with "why".  While those "why" questions have been the most interesting to answer (as well as the ones that cost me the most sleep), my favorite question to answer was "How does KERI support cryptographic agility, specifically how could it use new algorithms to provide post-quantum security?"  I believe Falcon was specifically mentioned as part of that question.

Tomorrow morning I will answer that question and with the help of Sam (of course) I was able to create a KERI inception event using Falcon-512 to generate public and next keys and sign the inception event.  I did this using the Open Quantum Safe library () with the python bindings () integrated into KERIpy.

Here is the inception event (with a hefty public key):

{
  "v": "KERI10JSON0005af_",
  "t": "icp",
  "d": "EI8G61z6s5c6-jrDSQ36eIx5wt-VV5T_Z_YMoZ6EyRKq",
  "i": "EI8G61z6s5c6-jrDSQ36eIx5wt-VV5T_Z_YMoZ6EyRKq",
  "s": "0",
  "kt": "1",
  "k": [
    "1AAKCYRxBesmbvgHwYeT2UuIHPlmYm0QTjoR_hiFKyKiSFyrdiELXrijOTJgWHAGWmpxChBdabDlKK_fFRwS4WBoHJpBZfBGblklAu304orZh42bUoTnRzDqcpkcYZwMWJhx3cmoicB29c3hShf2cNnak9tLMDMb2NgeoAxu-senZ0gV13U6zCgdsAzY3kR9ZIWMWCWA7Wb4vfW7HBqtwNFpqYyXSfLj6zsWhqYmM6rhgaorRgD0JdunibrZhrie96TY7TWQSfmfqWT5rMCSlzzOh3fGGRn1wTLlFoV4JkJYGOi9jDFX45gNO67--GVPS51tlWpnaZqzYqq3hu5WQgkdtOKyYkmWmrK1xQ-Wmj4JkzrmZmj4-zURxySRSvnWO6_KMyIZp70q7AxMHMF3LJ2QHsm1vQ8APPzPhgmdO7lm-AAILPaTylKbuB97KPZM5XsUy0Kcg7MDL8ygqqqBh9D3FGlUOsXj3HtwtwTLAuAy8CPyeufUGzGz5diV_hnsuYpNgJ0UZRt4YIZGMsV209pBlIT1FJqwULe_oVJrr9uyi5KKERXocXZtoGcKryxlNp6wzZKxZ7z9lyCpTEuyeYi5TU-YKlP3ndaCcf7H1GEXhoBo6ml0klU3gOdgzm9LmtgGKyiIwBPuaaJG6jEMcFHQOkQiA90PqzzQHJNEqiMzz9itIYQ69YpmcOFbNQHaowUF9QvlJgxgGB2KBkK1hyWz55ZGrDCUHZm1ERxzrZxT3KtDJN5otelr6DJ6r-MGGAqpxiMx32X3MDJQQ2qOzl3k1UM0Ya60FgMBSmXHjeBPkEaILmUgdCH8GcqCGEyWQ0XHvN5G8ZIF5QyghtSM7VYugB8IGtdlqQLPwShANwCRIWXz3bm04RcElRoLljy0qpoYDRUaI8r83M5AvLrHkO96shjWwgTeTbpcwNMKLXMQyDCEVo-yk7hGYE1iABIxqSvL2bM_JZ2QHcV9D6qB-DUXvW5c0eJanGVqxes1h9xNmnHS4mJQmU2paJlvGpAc4buYvJgeocbK1xMh-qYh51eIC-ZQ0LnVNs8QmDox0lzqkXblFpLFK92eQMKBYGEkRMa9E_2duwuyWRGMYxQxcbmB6m2yRoJpZG4lcbxOSWZnh-GM2WD1EtTXH3VL2EULN0cIFwlEKupNYpulUGs-XJRDNC1iPXNxTqXeSxeSsQKivgaz"

pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-03T04:14:01.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I will push my branch to WebOfTrust/keripy with the new (experimental) derivation codes and use of `liboqs` and python bindings to create keys and sign the event.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-03T04:24:07.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
One of the "why" questions I have to answer is "why did Sam create something new (CESR) instead of using what we already have (CBOR, COSE, Multi-Codec)?"

The answer is very clear to me now.  We believe that all data in the future will need to be authentic data and therefore, cryptographic primitives (AIDs, key digests, signatures) will be included with every bit of data transmitted and stored across the internet.  Those primitives must be represented as strings and not data structures to ensure we are able to ship the most compact form of those primitives.  CESR is the only encoding format that enables us to ship cryptographic primitives as first class encoded strings that are more compact than CBOR structures of the same data and even more compact when shipped as binary.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-03T04:25:57.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
When you look at the size of that public key and signature that we will have to use to be post-quantum secure you can see why this is so important.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-02-03T10:00:28.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Phil this is great for me to explain to people to help them understand why all this stuff is so important. This was a point I was missing when I described why we are going in the direction we are. Really appreciate it. It was the same argument, really, when I worked at Certicom. We were into ECC when everyone was using RSA, and additionally our implementations were so optimized for specific platforms that they were able to operate in constrained environments where others weren't. Decentralized identity is going to need to be deployed in a similar fashion, it isn't all laptops and mobile phones.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

I know that  adopts KERI as its core key-management technology. However, are there any other commercial services that also use KERI as its key management technology?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 5

				
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2023-02-04T07:35:07.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I know about few in telecom, supply chain, IoT and data processing, KERI is great as a base for creating decentralized governance so anywhere where you deal with diverse ecosystem it would fit perfectly. Companies starting adopting this technology after realizing dead end with their blockchain pilots. At Human Colossus Foundation we created for that purpose Colossi Network which is a network of private companies adopting and implementing technologies of Dynamic Data Economy (one of them is KERI).

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
2byrds

								
2023-02-04T07:35:07.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U013F46SDRR> and others, we just finished a meeting where a group is considering SSI adoption in an IoT use case where key rotation, performance, scale, management are all important (variety of devices and want to use similar identifiers for people as well as devices, etc). Any help/tips/pointers/pros/cons of using KERI for IoT… and even comparison between KERI and DID based stacks… and of course comparison between KERI and traditional Certificat Authority mechanisms are all welcome.  <@U03RLLP2CR5> presentation is helpful .  I also recently found this video about DIDs/IoT anchored to a blockchain 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2023-02-04T07:35:07.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
We touched on that topic multiple times during various community calls, long story short you can't get better then that, means KERI architecture fits perfectly into that space (as many others) if you think about accuracy of information or even simply device management in divers ecosystem DKMS beats anything which you can compare with. Why because it is agnostic to the ecosystem means you can do it simple in centralized highly controlled ecosystem but as well implement it in highly divers and decentralized/federated as well.
There are different technical solutions which can be applied depending on the use case based on that approach. IoT space is so vast that hard to just simply give short pros/cons. Since you didn't brought any specific "KERI vs xyz" or "KERI for zyx" I can share that it fits extremely well, and we start seeing some commercial adoption in that space at scale (really big scale and very sensitive). If you are interested in more details I will be presenting that topic on Identity Week in Amsterdam (June 14th)  (I have few limited VIP tickets to distribute for that event, those who will prove they are worthy :wink: happy to share). We also provide consulting services where we can roll out in details pros and cons tailored for interested use case.

P.S. decentralized IAM based on blockchain is not decentralized - I don't think that needs to be explained in that group :wink:
and if you want to compare it to DID, very high level description can be found here: 
DIDs are not secure (with few exception) this is why KERI come to existence to solve that problem.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
robert.mitwicki

								
2023-02-04T07:35:07.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
For individuals with an interest in the domains of Internet of Things (IoT) and Supply Chain, I wish to draw attention to my upcoming seminar session on this subject at Identity Week Europe 2023 in Amsterdam. The session will take place on the 13th of June at 15:20, during which I will illustrate how advanced technologies such as KERI, ACDC, Microledger and OCA can be utilized to address issues in diverse, cross-jurisdictional domains, supported by concrete examples in cold chain and IoT sectors, underpinned by DDE stack.

P.S. as mentioned in previous post still have few VIP tickets to distribute, PM me if you are interested.
