jason

            	
2023-02-05T11:30:00.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Last ACDC meeting, near the end, Daniel asked a question and I came up with a potential solution to it by concatenating two identifiers to form a single one. The idea was that a namespace would be hashed to provide the first part of the identifier, and a complete data structure to provide the rest. I’ll now give a complete description that I believe will create an auto-governing system, potentially addressing Phil’s concern. Sorry for not using the typical one letter identifiers, I don’t know them off the top so I’m going to be verbose so that I can communicate clearly.


{
  namespace: {
   digest: "E...",
   name: "xyz.qui.domain.identifier",
   issuer: "did:keri:E.."
  }
  digest: "E...",
  version: "0.1.0",
  // other data
}


If we combine (`namespace.digest` | `digest`), we can create a fixed-length searchable (by digest of issuer and name) versioning system where only the identified issuer can create versions of their data. There is no administration required, I believe. The trick is that `issuer` is an input to `namespace.digest`, and `namespace.digest` is an input to `digest` (we could use a compact expression of this information). The caveats:
• to allow this data to enter such a system, one needs it to be signed by the issuer
• to prevent abuse, one needs to ensure that one has the ability to throttle/cap by issuer id (unless, I suppose, resources are unconstrained?)
• consumers would be pulling _all_ versions for a given `name`/`issuer` pair
Is this new/useful/flawed?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-05T16:01:06.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
What would prevent another issuer to register the exact same name?  How then would someone tell which is the correct hash?

I feel like namespacing is for human readability to bridge between what a human sees and understanding it’s the correct issuer (for example). So I’m not sure what digesting the namespace buys us here. 

Namespace is a reputation issue and therefore should be resolved by trust anchors, not any central registry. 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

hvancann

            	
2023-02-06T01:11:03.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
A small _side step_: Validate, verify, validator en verifier are terms we might have to reiterate now and again. In our domain (KERI/ACDC) we seem to be able to work within the broader eSSIF-lab definitions. Mind you, the __ definition is very general, in the KERI/ACDC vocabulary ‘validate’ currently has diverse meanings including this one.

 (general)
**, of determining whether or not that data is valid to be used for some specific purpose(s) of that **.

 (general)
**, of determining whether that data is *authentic* (i.e. originates from the ** that authored it), timely (i.e. has not expired), and conforms to other specifications that apply to its structure.

In the KERI/ACDC domain we have come here:



If your border case / criterium is authenticity, as one could understand from “Validated meaning there is some signed chain going back to a root that validates the issuer as a member”, then first part of the sentence is what a verifier in KERI/ACDC in a narrow sense does, the second part ‘validate as a member’ is more a validator’s role.
Example: You keypass of the hotel might verify, the doorman might still not validate you as a guest allowed inside (validation).

It’s all about what we as a group collectively understand how individual members look at the criteria to draw lines between closely related terms in our terminology, even if borders between certain terms are vague. At the same time it would come in very handy if the outside world, outside of KERI/ACDC would still know what we’re talking about.
“I first have to try to understand what you mean, and then we might enjoy the bliss of reversal.”
I pass the baton back to Phil / Jason.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 2

				
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-06T01:11:03.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Right, and that was why I used the word validated - because it wasn't just a verification that was required to ensure participation allowance in the system, and I guess this is what Phil was talking about - that gating of participation makes the system still dependent on some type of business level decision.

I actually take great issue with people saying 'hash' when they mean 'digest'. A hash is a function that produces a digest. They aren't technically the same thing (or never were), but everyone uses them interchangeably.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-06T01:11:03.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
What I mean is - some business decision, in my scenario, is involved in admitting the participant in the first place.

Right, and that was why I used the word validated - because it wasn't just a verification that was required to ensure participation allowance in the system, and I guess this is what Phil was talking about - that gating of participation makes the system still dependent on some type of business level decision.

I actually take great issue with people saying 'hash' when they mean 'digest'. A hash is a function that produces a digest. They aren't technically the same thing (or never were), but everyone uses them interchangeably.

pdm

            	
2023-02-09T17:24:39.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Sorry if this is the wrong channel, but I have a question about KERI messages, and specifically the interpretation of the `kt` (key signing threshold) field. In some instances, the value of this field is a list of strings (representing fractionally weighted thresholds), and in others, it is a string, representing an P-of-Q condition, where P is the integer value in the field and Q is the length of the `k` (list of signing keys) field. In terms of an interpretation of these two different value types, would it be correct to assert the following equivalence?

`"kt": "N"`  is the same as `"kt": [ "1/N", "1/N", ... ]` where `len(kt) == len(k)`  and for all `0 <= i < len(kt)` , `kt[i] == "1/N"`

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-09T17:40:07.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Yes, a single number threshold that is less than the total number of keys is a simpler expression of an equivalent  fractionally weighted threshold.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-02-09T19:21:11.000Z

griffin.kev

            	
2023-02-12T22:18:01.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
KERI is a protocol developed by Dr Sam Smith, keripy is the reference implementation of that protocol.

There is a white paper and draft IETF specification along with it.

CESR, ACDC, PTEL, SAID are all derivatives that have been extracted from, or developed from the original white paper by Sam or <@U024CJMG22J> primarily, it’s open source so obviously there are other contributions.

There is no one over arching organization, that’s the great thing, we get contributions from a variety of companies.

<@U04HQD29Z7E> has a good point, there was a split over the introduction of a European copy left license for a variety of reasons.

Sams original idea was to use IETF to harbor specifications and Apache2 to foster implementations.

His reasoning he documented in the WebOfTrust/keri readme I believe.

Welcome! Hopefully we can answer any questions you have.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2023-02-12T23:11:10.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
We have started from scratch with cesr/parside, the short version is: CESR is a sub spec of keri and is often deemed the “hard bit” to implement making adoption harder.

We decided to start from scratch and model closer to keripy (which fully implements cesr) than what was previously out there.

As Sam continues to develop cesr, keripy will likely remain the spearhead of development, libraries downstream (in my opinion) will benefit from being closer to keripy (harboring a common vernacular etc)

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2023-02-12T23:14:26.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Do not discount the THC work though if you’re looking at rust, they have a very comprehensive write up on their license and why.

So again it depends on what you’re doing.

cesride is designed to be purely the primitives required for cesr, that might not be what you want right off the bat. Parside will consume cesride and represent the parsing module of keripy

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2023-02-12T23:15:08.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
We feel that is a good basis for further development

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2023-02-12T23:19:19.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
But Jason said it, meetings are a good place :)

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
2byrds

            	
2023-02-15T15:54:03.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U013F46SDRR> and others, we just finished a meeting where a group is considering SSI adoption in an IoT use case where key rotation, performance, scale, management are all important (variety of devices and want to use similar identifiers for people as well as devices, etc). Any help/tips/pointers/pros/cons of using KERI for IoT… and even comparison between KERI and DID based stacks… and of course comparison between KERI and traditional Certificat Authority mechanisms are all welcome.  <@U03RLLP2CR5> presentation is helpful .  I also recently found this video about DIDs/IoT anchored to a blockchain 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
robert.mitwicki

            	
2023-02-15T16:57:17.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
We touched on that topic multiple times during various community calls, long story short you can't get better then that, means KERI architecture fits perfectly into that space (as many others) if you think about accuracy of information or even simply device management in divers ecosystem DKMS beats anything which you can compare with. Why because it is agnostic to the ecosystem means you can do it simple in centralized highly controlled ecosystem but as well implement it in highly divers and decentralized/federated as well.
There are different technical solutions which can be applied depending on the use case based on that approach. IoT space is so vast that hard to just simply give short pros/cons. Since you didn't brought any specific "KERI vs xyz" or "KERI for zyx" I can share that it fits extremely well, and we start seeing some commercial adoption in that space at scale (really big scale and very sensitive). If you are interested in more details I will be presenting that topic on Identity Week in Amsterdam (June 14th)  (I have few limited VIP tickets to distribute for that event, those who will prove they are worthy :wink: happy to share). We also provide consulting services where we can roll out in details pros and cons tailored for interested use case.

P.S. decentralized IAM based on blockchain is not decentralized - I don't think that needs to be explained in that group :wink:
and if you want to compare it to DID, very high level description can be found here: 
DIDs are not secure (with few exception) this is why KERI come to existence to solve that problem.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
nuttawut.kongsuwan

            	
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I am reading the KERI white paper and came across the fact that KEL is considered a secondary root of trust (Page 60/141, Section 7.35).

In my understanding (which seems to be wrong), the controller of a transferrable AID—where the inception key is already rotated—needs both the current signing key and a KEL to cryptographically prove their control authority over the AID. Hence, my previous understanding was that the AID together with its KEL acts collectively as the primary root of trust.

I would really appreciate it if someone is willing to clarify this point.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 14

				
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
It is important to remember that KERI's security is based on the layering of thresholds.  The whole is greater than the sum of it's parts.

So while it seems that with a transferable identifier (one that can be rotated), the security of the identifier starts with its KEL, it does not.

As with all identifier types (transferable and non-transferable), the security starts with entropy.  The randomness used to create the private key is the absolute root of trust.  Once you create the private key you retain the ability to prove control over your identifier by your ability to use the private key.

With non-transferable identifiers, it ends there.  With transferable identifiers, the next root of trust (and thus a secondary root of trust) is the KEL which provides the ability to rotate the keys of the identifier.

Additional roots-of-trust layered on top of entropy and KELs include multi-sig support, delegation and witnesses.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
nuttawut.kongsuwan

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
That clarifies it. Thank you!

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Added to the Q-and-A, that’ll appear on the education site soon.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
In every cryptographic system entropy rules, and if you don't use a good rng (a csprng) you're boned from the start. This is really important for everyone in the space to understand. I knew a guy who was really into measuring hamming weights of outputs for everything he did as a crude way of ensuring sufficient entropy in the things he built.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I mostly used random generators that came from main crypto libraries. How can we know if there are good or not. Is there a list of libraries that we should consider using in out projects, or a list of the ones that we should never use?

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Generally you want to use the one supplied by the operating system. In linux this used to be `/dev/urandom` I believe but there was another one that wasn't cryptographic (the tradeoff must be speed, I've never read about it though I have implemented a prng or two).

In Rust you typically use `OsRng` from the random crate in fashion. In `cesride` we rely on two variants due to the expectations of `ed25519-dalek` and `k256`, and we simply pass them to the libraries to generate keys. You'd need to investigate how to get random bits in whatever language you are using, and just make sure what you are reading is about a `csprng` and not just an `rng` or `prng`.

This looks like it has a lot of good info, though I'm a bit lazy about reading it today:


								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
And, even a good `csprng` should be seeded well - if you can get random data from measuring user input or environmental conditions that can't be easily controlled you will generally be more resistant to attack. Think about the case for example, where a designer is tempted to use a radio receiver and noise to seed the RNG, but an attacker floods the space with a frequency that produces a deterministic result in the ADC or something.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
interesting. Thanks! Often we take care of a lot of things, but not the bare basic ones

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I'm questioning now whether `/dev/urandom` is actually an RNG or just a source of entropy, and used to seed an RNG. I won't be looking it up at the moment but don't want to mislead so read further if it is important.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Good discussion, I conclude that urandom is at least a PRNG. I’ve created this stuff:


and entries in the Q-and-A.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Here's a way to view entropy on the command line (should work in Linux and macOS):
```cat /dev/urandom | od -tx1 -Ax```
if you want a specific number of bytes, something like:
```dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=32 > entropy
cat entropy | od -tx1 -Ax```

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I'd also recommend trying out WSL2 in Windows if you are unfamiliar, for a more consistent dev experience across platforms - you should have `urandom` in there too.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
In KERIpy we use libsodium through the python bindings.  I've never actually looked at what their documentation says about randomness, but here it is:

>  The library provides a set of functions to generate unpredictable data, suitable for creating secret keys.
> • On Windows systems, the `RtlGenRandom()` function is used.
> • On OpenBSD and Bitrig, the `arc4random()` function is used.
> • On recent FreeBSD and Linux kernels, the `getrandom` system call is used.
> • On other Unices, the `/dev/urandom` device is used.
Thought that was interesting based on this conversation.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-02-19T02:27:56.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I extended the answer with Philip’s input in the related Q&A entry

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-02-19T03:26:40.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
It is important to remember that KERI's security is based on the layering of thresholds.  The whole is greater than the sum of it's parts.

So while it seems that with a transferable identifier (one that can be rotated), the security of the identifier starts with its KEL, it does not.

As with all identifier types (transferable and non-transferable), the security starts with entropy.  The randomness used to create the private key is the absolute root of trust.  Once you create the private key you retain the ability to prove control over your identifier by your ability to use the private key.

With non-transferable identifiers, it ends there.  With transferable identifiers, the next root of trust (and thus a secondary root of trust) is the KEL which provides the ability to rotate the keys of the identifier.

Additional roots-of-trust layered on top of entropy and KELs include multi-sig support, delegation and witnesses.

Generally you want to use the one supplied by the operating system. In linux this used to be `/dev/urandom` I believe but there was another one that wasn't cryptographic (the tradeoff must be speed, I've never read about it though I have implemented a prng or two).

2023-02-19T18:09:35.000Z

>  The library provides a set of functions to generate unpredictable data, suitable for creating secret keys.

Information on *DNS & Identity* and *Jacques Latour* (CTO of CIRA - Canada Internet Registrar/Registration Authority) , who is advocating for leveraging current DNS tech/tech direction vs.  attempting to replace it.

Contact info:
• @Jacques Latour (on ToIP Slack)
•

• Michael Palage () –

rodolfo.miranda

            	
2023-02-23T11:05:34.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Yesterday I presented to the Aries WG the did:keri method as an alternative to did:peer. You can find the recording at the end of this  (that recording, starting at min 21:20,  can be also  useful for those who weren’t at the KERI meeting when I presented the topic  weeks ago since it was not recorded).
The Aries WG has now the task to compare different candidates: did:peer:1, did:peer:2, did:keri, did:legacypeer and make a recomendation. Quote with what they are looking to compare:

- Verifying and document that the transformation can be made in each case — e.g. from unqualified DID and related DIDDoc to the new format — and what extra information and libraries would have to be defined/used for each.
- Create a spreadsheet of the properties that we get from each so that we have a comparison — size of DID, key rotation, ease of transformation, future path, multi-key support etc. Some will be subjective, but I think we have them in one place, it might be easier to see the differences.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
griffin.kev

            	
2023-03-01T00:21:08.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I have a polite request I'd like to make.

Our little KERI World community is growing, over the past couple of years we've incorporated a lot of new projects, CESR, ACDC, the entire vLEI ecosystem. We've seen production deployments and proof of concepts, we've done (more than I can count) presentations, we've had people attend conferences and represent this community. We're writing specifications and pushing for recognized standards for the work this community does.

However, KERI World (this Slack) and the Web Of Trust repositories are not a traditional standards organization, there's no paid infrastructure. There are no full time people who support it, it is literally a community of volunteers working together under a banner of like-mindedness.

This Slack is not Stack Overflow for KERI, we can't scale to that, there just is not enough of us.

My polite request is this, introduce yourself.

Introduce the work you're doing (so we can be excited about it with you!), if you haven't been to a KERI/ACDC/CESR call, do so, it's great to put faces to names and it is how our community grows closer and stronger together.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
robert.mitwicki

            	
2023-03-01T10:57:27.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
For individuals with an interest in the domains of Internet of Things (IoT) and Supply Chain, I wish to draw attention to my upcoming seminar session on this subject at Identity Week Europe 2023 in Amsterdam. The session will take place on the 13th of June at 15:20, during which I will illustrate how advanced technologies such as KERI, ACDC, Microledger and OCA can be utilized to address issues in diverse, cross-jurisdictional domains, supported by concrete examples in cold chain and IoT sectors, underpinned by DDE stack.

P.S. as mentioned in previous post still have few VIP tickets to distribute, PM me if you are interested.

hvancann

            	
2023-03-08T10:28:42.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
In this article of Christopher Allen, GLEIF is mentioned, as an example source of (undesirable) crypto agility. I can't see why, yet. 
What do you think? 


            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

            	
2023-03-08T10:32:10.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Allen mentions GLEIF also in the rwot community channel. I've asked for clarification.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
hvancann

            	
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Clarification by Christopher that we got: “GLEIF appears to be adopting many of the design patterns of JOSE, which is an example of the perils of cryptographic agility.”

Are we on the same page, or are we mixing up LEI and vLEI?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 8

				
						

							

								
								
vsuvorov

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I believe he's simply referring to the fact that various cryptographic primitives can be used. Such as various hash methods or signatures.

The danger of cryptographic agility is simply that libraries can be poorly implemented and not follow proper verification logic. Which was famously the case with JOSE/JWTs ( e.g. headers are  ). Another gotcha is that people will use poor choices when configuring keys, selecting algorithms, etc.  That's what `nacl` is helping to avoid. Or `paseto` tokens, etc.

Lastly, it adds complexity  to the processing logic and therefore potential bugs, including side channels. See TLS crypto suits ( e.g. downgrade attacks).

From my standpoint ( and I'm not a cryptographer) KERI is using cryptographic agility justifiably:
• new type or stronger key algos can be used in the future for transferable prefixes. 
• the set of primitives is relatively small and is easy to reason about. 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think so too. I still don’t understand why he explicit puts GLEIF in the spotlight for this; there are thousands of projects that meet those criteria (even better). Why GLEIF.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
vsuvorov

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I guess it's because GLEIF is a high profile project which is also a first mover to adapt a brand new cryptography based tech ( cryptographers are usually highly suspicious of any new efforts in that space).
 And he's probably biased towards , which arguably targets the same space and challenges as KERI/ACDC. :)

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think Vasily is correct here.  He is confusing KERI's support of cryptographic agility, which means support for multiple algorithms with the problems JOSE had because they allowed flexibility is selection of parameters for specific algorithms.  The later allowed for downgrading security by making poor choices in the parameters.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U024CJMG22J> so my (personal) reply to Chris about his remark “GLEIF appears to be adopting many of the design patterns of JOSE, which is an example of the perils of cryptographic agility.” could be:

According to the KERI/CESR/ACDC team behind the GLEIF vLEI implementation you might be confusing KERI’s support of cryptographic agility, which means support for multiple algorithms. The current KERI suite uses relatively dumb but seasoned cryptography.
The problems JOSE had because they allowed flexibility is selection of parameters for specific algorithms. The latter allowed for downgrading security by making poor choices in the parameters. This is not the case at GLEIF nor in the KERI stack.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Yes Henk, that is spot on!

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
It is ironic that Christopher specifically mentions GLEIF as the vLEI EGF ties down the cryptographic algorithms that are allowed to ed25519 and Blake3, meaning the vLEI is even less agile than KERI itself.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-03-08T11:56:23.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Very uneducated article if you ask me

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
vsuvorov

            	
2023-03-08T12:30:21.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I believe he's simply referring to the fact that various cryptographic primitives can be used. Such as various hash methods or signatures.

The danger of cryptographic agility is simply that libraries can be poorly implemented and not follow proper verification logic. Which was famously the case with JOSE/JWTs ( e.g. headers are  ). Another gotcha is that people will use poor choices when configuring keys, selecting algorithms, etc.  That's what `nacl` is helping to avoid. Or `paseto` tokens, etc.

Lastly, it adds complexity  to the processing logic and therefore potential bugs, including side channels. See TLS crypto suits ( e.g. downgrade attacks).

From my standpoint ( and I'm not a cryptographer) KERI is using cryptographic agility justifiably:
• new type or stronger key algos can be used in the future for transferable prefixes. 
• the set of primitives is relatively small and is easy to reason about.

According to the KERI/CESR/ACDC team behind the GLEIF vLEI implementation you might be confusing KERI’s support of cryptographic agility, which means support for multiple algorithms. The current KERI suite uses relatively dumb but seasoned cryptography.
The problems JOSE had because they allowed flexibility is selection of parameters for specific algorithms. The latter allowed for downgrading security by making poor choices in the parameters. This is not the case at GLEIF nor in the KERI stack.

pfeairheller

            	
2023-03-09T14:32:31.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
It is ironic that Christopher specifically mentions GLEIF as the vLEI EGF ties down the cryptographic algorithms that are allowed to ed25519 and Blake3, meaning the vLEI is even less agile than KERI itself.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

Post your reply (vote) of where (which WoT repo) the KERI ecosystem *scrapbook* should belong.  This scrapbook will capture the latest activities, vids, releases, guides, etc. in chronological order. Ideally it will be a markdown file and be available as a page on the web. Practically speaking it should highlight how active/vibrant the KERI/ACDC/GLEIF ecosystem is and helps people find the latest activity first. For instance at the top should be the link to the  and a little further down would be Daniel’s recent . It would be somewhat similar to  but a stream of latest activity so you get a sense of the age of the resource

The Nostr protocol is getting a lot of steam. Jack Dorsey (former twitter CEO) has focused on web3. Nostr is the new Decentralized Twitter. Many of the bitcoiners are using it. Creating a Nostr “account” seems a lot like SSI

2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
The issue with the way it is defined now, as I see it, is that they use raw public keys rather than KERI identifiers which was probably done for simplicity. There is nothing saying KERI couldn't back this kind of system, and in fact if everyone was using non-transferable keys many things probably simplify, but the user wouldn't be able to retain control of their account in the case of compromise. If instead, a message was tagged with an identifier, the solution becomes more complex but users can recover and protect their account.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I only researched for a short time, so someone please correct me if my understanding is wrong.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Thanks for taking a look Jason. Again from a top level, I'm interested it how a new user would be in introduced to Keri identifiers. OOBI or otherwise. I assume they wouldn't care or don't need to know it is Keri. I assume it would be some contact card on steroids analogy.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Or maybe there is something similar to the oauth workflow that is just more KERI centric

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I am just a very top-down thinker and I don't feel like I have been given a user-centered top view yet.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Imagine these two scenarios to start:

1. You want to purchase a bottle of wine and need to prove your age, but your driver's license contains all kinds of information you'd rather not share with the staff. Instead of giving them an id, you scan a QR code on their device and begin OOBI with the seller, and begin an exchange process of graduated and selective disclosure that ensure that if you have a credential or ACDC with appropriate chain of authority (back to something like a governmental body) proving you are 19, proof of this and your authentic, unexpired id photo is presented for verification by the employee via the exchange. Their system allows them to approve the sale, and you haven't disclosed your address etc.
2. You are arriving at the hospital and dread filling out forms. No need! With ACDCs issued via KERI and their associated records, proven authentic and signed by doctors and institutions, you can enter the hospital without filling any kind of forms.
These are the two examples that unlocked the most new use cases in my mind for decentralized id in general. There are so many more.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I'm not sure if that's the kind of top down thing that will help you, maybe if you give me more guidance I can explain more of what I have thought about.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Those are great examples. I have thought of many more scenarios as well. It’s roughly starting to take shape.

The way you described the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” made it sound a little like the OpenID/OAuth workflow — where interacting with a third party consists of:
#1) Choose an Identity Provider you want to use for interaction.
#2) Sign-in to chosen Identity Provider.
#3) “Review and Accept”, or “Review and Select” what data that will be exposed to the third party.

Whereas, the KERI SSI flow would be something like:
#1) Choose the KERI SSI option as an Identity Provider (no need to sign in, because your keys will be used). Then, if I have never completed the “Alcoholic Beverage Age Proof” with this vendor, I must:
#2) Choose an “Age Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my age.
#3) Choose a “Photo Disclosure” from a list of acceptable options for providing my photo.

Where, for each disclosure, the third party has pre-selected the “list of acceptable” providers for their specific trust/reputation tolerance level.

Also, the first time you do this, your choices are saved (as an ACDC?), so the next time these disclosures are presented, you will not need to select them again. And the process will end with #1, making for a better user experience.

Additionally, any other third party that requires an “Age Disclosure” or “Photo Disclosure” and accepts the providers chosen will automatically resolve. Again, resulting in a better user experience.

At least, that is what I would imagine.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U0448S72CQN> here is mine

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I followed you!

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
trent

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Back at ya!

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
One little thing to mention: Jack Dorsey hired Daniel Buchner. Buchner is the father of ION and Sidetree and explicit critic of KERI. Not always based on fundamental knowledge, but bias, imho. There’ve been heated discussions between Sam and Daniel Buchner in the past, where Daniel proved to not fully understand KERI and still dismiss it.
So I don’t think KERI gets a warm reception at Nostr while Buchner is the CTO.
However, I experienced Daniel as a friendly helpful guy the time that I documented Q&As for ION and Sidetree.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I have an anecdote: If I recall correctly, in a EFWG meeting when I first entered the space I asked Daniel directly if the DWN solution had provisions in it for the strong binding between identifier and keys that KERI allows by virtue of the identifier being a commitment to/derivation of inception. He replied 'KERI is a witness network! It's not the same thing. Of course we have cryptographically bound our keys to our identifiers.' I didn't understand at the time what DID methods were, etc, but I am quite sure he totally missed what I was asking, as he didn't provide any analysis, reasoning, or explanation that educated me. To the best of my knowledge the criticism is unfounded but I am not the right person to comment.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Also the pre-committed rotation of course, binds every subsequent set of keys to the identifier/inception. That was the feature I had trouble finding elsewhere. ACDC was just icing on the cake when I learned about it.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U04PXR871PS> There were some long threads in Issues and in Slack channel(s) at DIF KERI back then.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
hvancann

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I found an example for you 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Thanks for sharing Henk! I had no idea this existed. Here's the money post imo: 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-16T14:15:44.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Also for those following, another really cool feature besides the strong identifier/key binding in KERI is delegation.

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-03-20T11:18:27.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Also the pre-committed rotation of course, binds every subsequent set of keys to the identifier/inception. That was the feature I had trouble finding elsewhere. ACDC was just icing on the cake when I learned about it.

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
nuttawut.kongsuwan

            	
2023-03-21T02:51:15.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I have published my study note on the KERI whitepaper on Medium.
I tried to summarize the important concepts in the whitepaper, prioritizing readability over comprehensiveness.

I am not sure how useful this is for the community. But if anyone is willing to read and give feedback (or correction), I would really appreciate it. :slightly_smiling_face:


            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 5

				
						

							

								
								
vsuvorov

								
2023-03-21T02:51:15.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Very nice!  It'd be great to extend this a bit  and mark parts that are not implemented today and are in the planning. E.g. gossip between the witnesses, watcher role, etc.
The reason it's useful is that the white paper draws a big picture, a theory, whereas the implementation covers many but not all aspects. So for anyone who wishes to learn about Keri and then build some use-cases around it, the white paper is not enough.

BTW, there is a small typo at the beginning of the Blog : "*Part 2* dives into other peripheral topics in the KERI ecosystem such as Authentic Chained Data Containers _*(ACDA)"*_ - should be ACDC.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
nuttawut.kongsuwan

								
2023-03-21T02:51:15.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U04RNMG8Z51> thank you for spotting the typo.
Highlighting the features that have and have not been implemented sound like a good idea. Unfortunately, I am not well aware of the full extent of the current implementations.

A community’s feature roadmap does sound like something very useful.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-21T02:51:15.000Z

I recently made a comment for OIDC 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
joseph.l.hunsaker

            	
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
<@U04RNMG8Z51> :point_up:  is this a “high level” (user centric view) of what you image with OIDC?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 7

				
						

							

								
								
vsuvorov

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
In a way. OpenID for VC Issuance/Presentations is an extension to OpenID that would allow wallaets to receive and present credentials. So the scenario you are describing should be well supported. The great thing about the Spec is that any type of credentials can be exchanged, the spec is  "VC" format agnostic, if you will.  You can check it out .

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
vsuvorov

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Now ,the EU has recently  the Architecture Reference Framework for EU Digital Identity - an EU wide initiative for credential currying wallets. OpenID for Verifiable Credentials is at the center of the document. Which means that ACDCs can eventually be made part of it.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Does it say that the VC needs to be W3C VC?

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
based on  , the VC can be:
```Can be of any format used in the Issuer-Holder-Verifier Model, including, but not limited to those defined in [VC_DATA] and [ISO.18013-5]```
where VC_DATA is the w3c vc data model and  [ISO.18013-5] is mDL .

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
go for it then!!!

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think it's a good match from GLEIF, eIDAS, and DIDAS

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-03-21T14:45:20.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
<@U04RNMG8Z51>, you already mentioned that it's VC format agnostic. I missed your previous comment

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
vsuvorov

            	
2023-03-21T15:17:17.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
In a way. OpenID for VC Issuance/Presentations is an extension to OpenID that would allow wallaets to receive and present credentials. So the scenario you are describing should be well supported. The great thing about the Spec is that any type of credentials can be exchanged, the spec is  "VC" format agnostic, if you will.  You can check it out .

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
vsuvorov

            	
2023-03-21T15:21:27.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Now ,the EU has recently  the Architecture Reference Framework for EU Digital Identity - an EU wide initiative for credential currying wallets. OpenID for Verifiable Credentials is at the center of the document. Which means that ACDCs can eventually be made part of it.

based on  , the VC can be:

Can be of any format used in the Issuer-Holder-Verifier Model, including, but not limited to those defined in [VC_DATA] and [ISO.18013-5]
where VC_DATA is the w3c vc data model and  [ISO.18013-5] is mDL .

Are there any post quantum signature schemes implemented in CESR? I came across this  and realized that for any federal use case they will not accept vendors that do not use post quantum encryption schemes. I understand that they are worried about national security but would figure that big companies will follow suite soon

joseph.l.hunsaker

            	
2023-03-24T02:50:57.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Correct me if I am wrong, but in Sam’s ACDC presentation this week, I noticed that the “append to extend” model allowing back references forms a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 4

				
						

							

								
								
2byrds

								
2023-03-24T02:50:57.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Sam was explaining that the immutability of the DAG is important for append to extend to scale, maintaining verification of previous portions to be cached and making future verifications incremental

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
joseph.l.hunsaker

								
2023-03-24T02:50:57.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Wonderful

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
neil.thomson

								
2023-03-24T02:50:57.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Sam explains that in detail in the presentation he did on Mar 21 in the ToIP DMRWG call. I'll have the recording, meeting notes and slides in the next 24 hours.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-03-24T02:50:57.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
It's actually noted that ACDCs chain into a DAG in the intro paragraph of the IETF ACDC draft: 

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2023-03-24T14:22:28.000Z

kent

<@U024KC347B4>

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
WebOfTrust/Keep is intended to be the community reference implementation for a user interface.  It was donated by GLEIF but not maintained after the end of last year.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
A potentially wonderful contribution to the community would be integrating a TypeScript Signify client library into it and modifying the UI to work as a signing at the edge client.  I certainly don't have time to do anything with that.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

kent

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Is Signify-TS currently at a point where I could begin this work?

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
It has all the cryptographic primitives in it that it could be enhanced to act as a full Signify client.  The actual client / server interactions have not been added to it yet.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-13T21:21:10.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
A word of warning, we stopped working on the TS version because we are planning on integrating it with CESRide since it currently requires WASM for the cryptographic libraries anyway.  And once we thought of that, we have been wondering if we would just want to WASM in Signifide instead of writing any client code in TS.  Something we plan on talking about next week.

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
kent

            	
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I want to improve and simplify the process of agents discovering each other so connecting across KERI agents can be intuitive from a UX perspective for non-techies.
I am trying to simplify the user experience of connecting KERI Agents to one another and in so doing am looking to automate as much as possible. I want to understand conceptually why I can’t replace the manual OOBI and challenge phrase sharing with a step that is performed by some matchmaking or discovery server.

Essentially I’d like to have a mobile app have a listing of agents pre-loaded so that the user can just tap an agent to connect with, initiate an OOBI exchange, and then a challenge phrase workflow.
What security guarantees do I lose if I have a man-in-the middle matchmaking or discovery service facilitate this? Do I open myself up to man in the middle attacks or is everything still reasonably secure since OOBI resolution results in key state verification, which cannot be faked?

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 5

				
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
You are simply providing a discovery mechanism so as long as each user resolves the OOBI (and verifies key state for themselves) and then does a challenge response you have not sacrificed anything. 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Oobi is a way to map the AID with the URL where you can query the end verifiable kel. You can have those pairs in a DB or any place without decreasing security.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
But you are changing the dynamic of OOBI exchange. You are asking people to publish an OOBI which eliminates the ability to have 1-1 connections.  Not sure that helps anyone but public identifiers for thing like brands. 

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
rodolfo.miranda

								
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
And that you still need to find a way to share the AID and the challenge words

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
kent

								
2023-04-14T22:19:02.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Thanks Phil, this makes sense.

								
							

						

						
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-04-14T22:28:58.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
You are simply providing a discovery mechanism so as long as each user resolves the OOBI (and verifies key state for themselves) and then does a challenge response you have not sacrificed anything. 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2023-04-14T22:29:31.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Oobi is a way to map the AID with the URL where you can query the end verifiable kel. You can have those pairs in a DB or any place without decreasing security.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
pfeairheller

            	
2023-04-14T22:30:09.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
But you are changing the dynamic of OOBI exchange. You are asking people to publish an OOBI which eliminates the ability to have 1-1 connections.  Not sure that helps anyone but public identifiers for thing like brands. 

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
rodolfo.miranda

            	
2023-04-14T22:31:29.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
And that you still need to find a way to share the AID and the challenge words

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

2023-04-15T00:48:15.000Z

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
nuttawut.kongsuwan

            	
2023-04-21T01:45:50.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I was recommended to read this article at IIW. It seems there is a disagreement on whether to include specific did methods in the spec. One of the motivations that makes me adopt KERI is to avoid this mess entirely and just use AIDs.


“Summary of Technical Objection

Having the DID WG standardize specific DID methods creates moral hazards that will inevitably reduce the decentralization of DIDs themselves. Whichever methods the group chooses will attain unprecedented acceleration and impact. It will take an increased attention from the WG focused on those methods, taking away from attention that could go to advance all DID methods. That attention will also increase the WGs familiarity with how chosen methods solve certain problems and those approaches will necessarily already have the blessing of the WG, making them preferred favorites over approaches used by other methods. In short, giving the DID WG the permission to focus its attention on selected favorites would directly undermine its ability to advance the work with equal respect for all methods.”

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

jason

In the meantime, here's something very useful I distilled with a bit of work from <@U03EUG009MY>’s blog post:
```[

        "v": "KERI10JSON0001b7_",

        "ii": "EIaJ5gpHSL9nl1XIWDkfMth1uxbD-AfLkqdiZL6S7HkZ",
        "s": "0",
        "c": [
            "NB"
        ],
        "bt": "0",
        "b": [],
        "n": "AGHblRF4Vdcg_Q5Y4j7LTdFPR04qH4ARR2XrK-Xb6HRz"
    },
    {
        "v": "KERI10JSON00013a_",
        "t": "ixn",
        "d": "ED7MXKROzbMwLMnDojpcOnCLWYBMiDo0LY5DbCzy5TB-",
        "i": "EIaJ5gpHSL9nl1XIWDkfMth1uxbD-AfLkqdiZL6S7HkZ",
        "s": "1",
        "p": "EIaJ5gpHSL9nl1XIWDkfMth1uxbD-AfLkqdiZL6S7HkZ",

                "i": "EAuvxnObLjS8E2Yn9-7twA8_ZqEsMC3vispqy26NVdaW",

                "d": "EAuvxnObLjS8E2Yn9-7twA8_ZqEsMC3vispqy26NVdaW"
            }

    },

        "v": "ACDC10JSON0001d9_",

            "d": "EBLyBuP_LUGSP3cDUKxQiCe86Sh5J4R6XXqz2hjVEc5H",

        "ri": "EAuvxnObLjS8E2Yn9-7twA8_ZqEsMC3vispqy26NVdaW",
        "dt": "2023-04-23T09:10:37.698209+00:00"
    },
    {
        "v": "KERI10JSON00013a_",
        "t": "ixn",
        "d": "EKmNtSAju7d3KhdxzIdyZycZNgAWDKfW5YDRUy9eDHis",
        "i": "EIaJ5gpHSL9nl1XIWDkfMth1uxbD-AfLkqdiZL6S7HkZ",

        "p": "ED7MXKROzbMwLMnDojpcOnCLWYBMiDo0LY5DbCzy5TB-",

            {
                "i": "EKriPO1JGk369l5zJGzfFn-yS0dazYu0ktCg8h5pxKZ3",
                "s": "0",
                "d": "EHD81HVJGDhFWt82QCS_7II44Lqf9iO43ayt4aZ7wqWr"
            }
        ]
    }
]```
It's a full set of messages required to issue an ACDC (without sigs, but that's the easy part)

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Okay <@U03P53FCYB1> I think that's easiest too

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
If another person gives it a +1 I'll just do it

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
The tricky part about those messages was getting the issuance VC TEL event, and then figuring out the order. The trick to the ordering is that you highlight the `d` field in an editor and search for it, and ensure that the first occurrence is when it is the said of the top level entity. So essentially, go through the top level messages and for each `d` attribute near the beginning, do a search and make sure that one is #1.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I think it would be valuable to be able to say `kli vc complete -n name --prefix EKriPO1JGk369l5zJGzfFn-yS0dazYu0ktCg8h5pxKZ3` and get this stream of messages, with sigs. It's a portable, verifiable block of data supporting the acdc in question.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
maybe not complete, but something like it.

complete has a verb meaning

jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
For completeness, here's the schema used:
```{
    "$id": "EIxAox3KEhiQ_yCwXWeriQ3ruPWbgK94NDDkHAZCuP9l",
    "$schema": "",
    "title": "Treasure Hunting Journey",
    "description": "All of the facts regarding a treasure hunting journey including destination and treasure splits",
    "type": "object",
    "credentialType": "TreasureHuntingJourney",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "properties": {
        "v": {
            "description": "Credential Version",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "d": {
            "description": "Credential SAID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "u": {
            "description": "One time use nonce - optional",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "i": {
            "description": "Issuer AID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "ri": {
            "description": "Credential Registry Identifier",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "s": {
            "description": "Schema SAID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "a": {
            "oneOf": [
                {
                    "description": "Attributes block SAID",
                    "type": "string"
                },
                {
                    "$id": "EPfNU6jej4GGyprpakq6KCO9os9vp9jLIRcH1xJqVezj",
                    "description": "Attributes block",
                    "type": "object",
                    "properties": {
                        "d": {
                            "description": "Attributes block SAID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "i": {
                            "description": "Issuee AID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "dt": {
                            "description": "Issuance date time",
                            "type": "string",
                            "format": "date-time"
                        },
                        "destination": {
                            "description": "The target location for this journey where the hunters will go.",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "treasureSplit": {
                            "description": "The type of splits for this journey. 50/50, 25/25/25/25, and so forth. Must add up to 100.",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "partyThreshold": {
                            "description": "The minimum party member threshold needed to charter this journey",
                            "type": "integer"
                        },
                        "journeyEndorser": {
                            "description": "The AID of the ATHENA inner circle member endorsing this treasure hunting journey.",
                            "type": "string"
                        }
                    },
                    "additionalProperties": false,
                    "required": [
                        "i",
                        "destination",
                        "treasureSplit",
                        "partyThreshold",
                        "journeyEndorser"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        },
        "r": {
            "oneOf": [
                {
                    "description": "Rules block SAID",
                    "type": "string"
                },
                {
                    "$id": "ENe_FPWFO867EZ1HKQZwDu9GpDhpyGDFwwZFQYK8_ZaD",
                    "description": "Rules block",
                    "type": "object",
                    "properties": {
                        "d": {
                            "description": "Rules block SAID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "treasureSplitAgreement": {
                            "description": "Treasure Split Agreement",
                            "type": "object",
                            "properties": {
                                "l": {
                                    "description": "Associated legal language",
                                    "type": "string",
                                    "const": "Signing of the Treasure Hunting Journey split agreement binds the signers to split the treasure received from the journey according to the split terms specified.."
                                }
                            }
                        }
                    },
                    "additionalProperties": false,
                    "required": [
                        "d",
                        "treasureSplitAgreement"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    },
    "additionalProperties": false,
    "required": [
        "v",
        "i",
        "ri",
        "s",
        "d",
        "a"
    ]
}```

jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
As far as I could tell that only exports the ACDC, not the supporting KEL and TELs required to verify. I guess what I am saying is, if we could package up everything needed to verify an acdc, and then make chaining automagic and build a long, presequenced list of required messages to verify the last acdc in the chain (and the couple events that follow it), it would be great. I am going to build out that functionality for Qui, so I'll take a stab at adding it to the `kli` if you want.

```❯ kli vc export -n wiseman -a ramiel -s EOB9YVK7UY1BZ2gDWNcFLBMVzcOmPuh6DR6Yg1Zen9qV

pfeairheller

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I was surprised it didn't have that, I was going to check in the morning.  Order doesn't matter.  All implementations should assume that events are asynchronous and can arrive in any order.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
Now you can improve the performance of someone receiving your events for sure, but it should not be imperative.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
jason

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
I guess you could also juggle them when you got them, if you got them in a single package. I am trying to figure out how to get from A to B in small iterative steps, is all, rather than implementing the whole thing before I see pieces of it work.

								
							

						

						
						

							

								
								
pfeairheller

								
2023-04-23T18:42:28.000Z

							

							
							
    
								
We did do an optimization pass in credential issuance code to try to remove the need for the holder to have to escrow anything in a credential chain.  That is probably what you are looking for.  I'll see if I can find it in the morning.

        "i": "EKriPO1JGk369l5zJGzfFn-yS0dazYu0ktCg8h5pxKZ3",
        "s": "0",
        "ri": "EAuvxnObLjS8E2Yn9-7twA8_ZqEsMC3vispqy26NVdaW",
        "dt": "2023-04-23T09:10:37.698209+00:00"
    },
    {
        "v": "KERI10JSON00013a_",
        "t": "ixn",
        "d": "EKmNtSAju7d3KhdxzIdyZycZNgAWDKfW5YDRUy9eDHis",
        "i": "EIaJ5gpHSL9nl1XIWDkfMth1uxbD-AfLkqdiZL6S7HkZ",
        "s": "2",
        "p": "ED7MXKROzbMwLMnDojpcOnCLWYBMiDo0LY5DbCzy5TB-",
        "a": [
            {
                "i": "EKriPO1JGk369l5zJGzfFn-yS0dazYu0ktCg8h5pxKZ3",
                "s": "0",
                "d": "EHD81HVJGDhFWt82QCS_7II44Lqf9iO43ayt4aZ7wqWr"
            }
        ]
    }
]
It's a full set of messages required to issue an ACDC (without sigs, but that's the easy part)

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-04-23T18:49:18.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
Okay <@U03P53FCYB1> I think that's easiest too

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-04-23T18:51:45.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
The tricky part about those messages was getting the issuance VC TEL event, and then figuring out the order. The trick to the ordering is that you highlight the `d` field in an editor and search for it, and ensure that the first occurrence is when it is the said of the top level entity. So essentially, go through the top level messages and for each `d` attribute near the beginning, do a search and make sure that one is #1.

            	

			

			

    			
Number of replies: 0

				
  			

		

        
		

			

    			
  				
jason

            	
2023-04-23T18:53:25.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I think it would be valuable to be able to say `kli vc complete -n name --prefix EKriPO1JGk369l5zJGzfFn-yS0dazYu0ktCg8h5pxKZ3` and get this stream of messages, with sigs. It's a portable, verifiable block of data supporting the acdc in question.

jason

            	
2023-04-23T19:21:07.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
For completeness, here's the schema used:

{
    "$id": "EIxAox3KEhiQ_yCwXWeriQ3ruPWbgK94NDDkHAZCuP9l",
    "$schema": "",
    "title": "Treasure Hunting Journey",
    "description": "All of the facts regarding a treasure hunting journey including destination and treasure splits",
    "type": "object",
    "credentialType": "TreasureHuntingJourney",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "properties": {
        "v": {
            "description": "Credential Version",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "d": {
            "description": "Credential SAID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "u": {
            "description": "One time use nonce - optional",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "i": {
            "description": "Issuer AID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "ri": {
            "description": "Credential Registry Identifier",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "s": {
            "description": "Schema SAID",
            "type": "string"
        },
        "a": {
            "oneOf": [
                {
                    "description": "Attributes block SAID",
                    "type": "string"
                },
                {
                    "$id": "EPfNU6jej4GGyprpakq6KCO9os9vp9jLIRcH1xJqVezj",
                    "description": "Attributes block",
                    "type": "object",
                    "properties": {
                        "d": {
                            "description": "Attributes block SAID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "i": {
                            "description": "Issuee AID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "dt": {
                            "description": "Issuance date time",
                            "type": "string",
                            "format": "date-time"
                        },
                        "destination": {
                            "description": "The target location for this journey where the hunters will go.",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "treasureSplit": {
                            "description": "The type of splits for this journey. 50/50, 25/25/25/25, and so forth. Must add up to 100.",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "partyThreshold": {
                            "description": "The minimum party member threshold needed to charter this journey",
                            "type": "integer"
                        },
                        "journeyEndorser": {
                            "description": "The AID of the ATHENA inner circle member endorsing this treasure hunting journey.",
                            "type": "string"
                        }
                    },
                    "additionalProperties": false,
                    "required": [
                        "i",
                        "destination",
                        "treasureSplit",
                        "partyThreshold",
                        "journeyEndorser"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        },
        "r": {
            "oneOf": [
                {
                    "description": "Rules block SAID",
                    "type": "string"
                },
                {
                    "$id": "ENe_FPWFO867EZ1HKQZwDu9GpDhpyGDFwwZFQYK8_ZaD",
                    "description": "Rules block",
                    "type": "object",
                    "properties": {
                        "d": {
                            "description": "Rules block SAID",
                            "type": "string"
                        },
                        "treasureSplitAgreement": {
                            "description": "Treasure Split Agreement",
                            "type": "object",
                            "properties": {
                                "l": {
                                    "description": "Associated legal language",
                                    "type": "string",
                                    "const": "Signing of the Treasure Hunting Journey split agreement binds the signers to split the treasure received from the journey according to the split terms specified.."
                                }
                            }
                        }
                    },
                    "additionalProperties": false,
                    "required": [
                        "d",
                        "treasureSplitAgreement"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    },
    "additionalProperties": false,
    "required": [
        "v",
        "i",
        "ri",
        "s",
        "d",
        "a"
    ]
}

jason

            	
2023-04-23T19:58:17.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
As far as I could tell that only exports the ACDC, not the supporting KEL and TELs required to verify. I guess what I am saying is, if we could package up everything needed to verify an acdc, and then make chaining automagic and build a long, presequenced list of required messages to verify the last acdc in the chain (and the couple events that follow it), it would be great. I am going to build out that functionality for Qui, so I'll take a stab at adding it to the `kli` if you want.

kent

            	
2023-04-28T14:59:22.000Z

			

			
  			
    
            	
I have a client asking me for a list of companies that currently use KERI. I gave the following list.

1. GLEIF (first in the world)
2. Provenant (telecom)
3. Qui Identity (going live in about five weeks with non-custodial mobile wallets)
4. The Human Colossus Foundation in the EU. They have many different clients all using KERI and ACDC.
5. RootsID with a Cardano blockchain integration
Who else should be on that list?
